3. Previous reference (2/206-207).

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
16 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Repentance and returning to Allah. For when a servant falls into sin, the harshness, hardness, and angry quality that he had towards anyone from whom a sin issued leaves his heart - such that if he had power over him he would destroy him, and perhaps he would pray to Allah to destroy him and take him out of anger for the sake of Allah and keenness that He not be disobeyed. So he finds no mercy in his heart for the sinful wrongdoers and sees them only with the eye of contempt and disdain, and mentions them only with the tongue of defamation, fault-finding, and dispraise. But when the decrees run upon him and he is left alone with himself, he seeks help from Allah, takes refuge in Him, and writhes before Him like a snake-bitten person, and calls upon Him with the call of the desperate. So that harshness towards sinners changes into tenderness, and that hardness towards wrongdoers into mercy and softness while upholding the limits of Allah. And his supplication against them changes into supplication for them, and he makes it a duty of his life to ask Allah to forgive them. How beneficial is this scene for them, and how great is its benefit for him, and Allah knows best (1).
17 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Fear and caution of Allah. The believer in Predestination is cautious of Allah, for no one feels secure from the plan of Allah except the losing people. So he is not deluded by his deeds no matter how many they are. For the hearts are between two fingers of the fingers of the Most Merciful, He turns them however He wills, and the endings are known to Allah Almighty.
18 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Reliance (Tawakkul), certainty, submission to Allah, and dependence on Him. Because the servant's satisfaction with Allah's management of him implies singling Him out for reliance, seeking help, trust, and dependence, and being satisfied with everything He does to him. Ibn al-Qayyim said: (Section: And the Beautiful Names and Lofty Attributes necessitate their effects of servitude and command, just as they necessitate their effects of creation and formation - I mean from the requirements of knowing them and realizing them. This is consistent in all types of servitude that are upon the heart and limbs. So the servant's knowledge of the Lord Almighty's uniqueness in harm, benefit, giving, withholding, creation, provision, giving life, and causing death produces for him the servitude of reliance on Him inwardly, and the requirements of reliance and its fruits outwardly) (2). As Allah Almighty said: {Say, "Never will we be struck except by what Allah has decreed for us"} [At-Tawbah: 51]. (So he rests then from worries, distresses, miseries, and regrets. And he burdens his whole being, his needs, and his interests upon One who does not mind carrying them, nor does it burden Him, nor does He care about it [due to His power]. So He takes charge of them without him, and shows him His kindness, righteousness, mercy, and benevolence in them without fatigue from the servant, nor exhaustion, nor concern from him, because he has directed his concern entirely to Him, and made Him alone his concern. So He diverted from him his concern for his needs and worldly interests, and emptied his heart of them. How good is his life! And how blissful is his heart and great is his joy and happiness! But if he refuses anything but his own management for himself, and his choice for it, and his concern for his share - without the right of his Lord - He leaves him to what he chose, and entrusts him to what he took charge of. So worry, distress, sadness, misery, fear, fatigue, bad state of mind, and bad condition attend him. So no heart is pure, no deed is pure, no hope is achieved, no rest is won, and no pleasure is enjoyed. Rather, a barrier has been placed between him and his joy, happiness, and delight. He toils in the world like the toil of a wild beast, and does not achieve hope from it, nor does he provision himself from it for a return [to the Hereafter]) (3).
foot_note:
1. Previous reference (1/426).
2. Miftah Dar Al-Sa'adah p. (2/90), edition of the Presidency of Scientific Research and Ifta, Riyadh.
3. Al-Fawa'id p. 84-85.

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
Reliance on Allah and dependence on Him does not contradict taking means. The Prophet, peace be upon him, was asked about dropping means in view of Predestination? He rejected that and obligated taking means, as in the Sahih from him, peace be upon him, that he said: "There is none of you but his seat in Paradise and his seat in the Fire has been known. They said: O Messenger of Allah, shall we not leave acting and rely on the Book? He said: No, act, for everyone is facilitated for what he was created for" (1). The monotheist who relies [on Allah]: does not turn to causes, meaning he does not feel secure with them, nor hope in them nor fear them, so he does not lean on them. And he does not turn [away] from them - meaning he does not drop them nor neglect them nor cancel them - rather he is establishing them, paying attention to them, looking at their Causer, Glory be to Him, and their Conductor. So reliance is not valid - religiously and rationally - except upon Him, Glory be to Him, alone (2). How well said by the one who said: Eyes stayed awake and eyes slept ... In affairs that will be or will not be. Indeed, a Lord who sufficed you yesterday regarding what was ... Will suffice you tomorrow regarding what will be (3).
19 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: The good life. Allah Almighty says: {Whoever does righteousness, whether male or female, while he is a believer - We will surely cause him to live a good life, and We will surely reward them their due according to the best of what they used to do} [An-Nahl: 97]. So Allah Almighty informed and promised whoever combines faith and righteous deed with a good life in this abode, and with the good reward in this abode and in the Abode of Decision. The reason for that is clear, for the believers in Allah with correct faith - which includes belief in Predestination - which bears the fruit of righteous deed that reforms hearts, morals, this world and the Hereafter, have with them principles and foundations with which they receive all that comes upon them of causes of pleasure and joy, and causes of anxiety, worry and sorrows. They receive beloved things and joys with acceptance of them, gratitude for them, and using them in what is beneficial. If they use them in this manner, it creates for them joy in them, hope for their continuity and blessing, and hope for the reward of the thankful, great matters that surpass in their goodness and blessings these joys which are their fruits.
foot_note:
1. Previously referenced p. 12 footnote No. 3.
2. Madarij Al-Salikin (3/500).
3. Jaddid Hayatak, Muhammad Al-Ghazali p. 27, 9th Edition, Dar Al-Qalam Damascus, 1416 AH.

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
And they receive dislikes, harms, worry, and distress by resisting what they can resist, lightening what they can lighten, and beautiful patience for what they have no way to avoid. By that, they obtain from the effects of dislikes beneficial resistances, experiences, and strength, and from patience and seeking reward, great matters with which dislikes fade away, and joys and good hopes take their place, along with greed for Allah's favor and His reward. As the Prophet, peace be upon him, expressed this in the authentic hadith where he said: "How wonderful is the affair of the believer, for his affair is all good. If something good happens to him, he gives thanks, and that is good for him. If something bad happens to him, he endures it patiently, and that is good for him. And this is for no one but the believer" (1). So he, peace be upon him, informed that the believer's gain, good, and fruits of deeds multiply in everything that befalls him of joy and dislikes (2).
20 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: That belief in Predestination is a way of salvation from Shirk (polytheism). The Majus (Zoroastrians) claimed: That Light is the creator of good, and Darkness is the creator of evil. And the Qadariyyah said: That Allah did not create the actions of servants. So they affirmed creators alongside Allah - Mighty and Majestic - and this is Shirk. Belief in Predestination in the correct manner is Tawhid (monotheism) of Allah.
21 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Sincerity. Indeed, all actions and sayings are only valid and complete according to what is established in the heart of their doer of faith and sincerity. Therefore, Allah mentions this condition which is the basis of every deed. Allah Almighty says: {So whoever does righteous deeds while he is a believer - no denial will there be for his effort} [Al-Anbiya: 94]. So if deeds are founded upon faith, and built upon it, the effort is thanked, accepted, multiplied, not an atom's weight of it is lost. But if the deed lacks faith, even if the worker spends his night and day [in it], it is not accepted. Allah Almighty says: {And We will regard what they have done of deeds and make them as scattered dust (23)} [Al-Furqan: 23] (3). (Belief in Predestination saves the servant from pleasing people with the wrath of Allah, and from blaming them for what Allah did not give him, and from praising them for what is the very favor of Allah. So he would be unjust to them in the first: which is pleasing and blaming them, and associating partners with them in the second: which is praising them. So if he is satisfied with the decree, he is saved from blaming and praising them. So satisfaction saves him from all that) (4). So the one who believes in Predestination does not work for the sake of people, knowing that they will not benefit him except with something Allah has written for him.
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim, Book of Zuhd, Chapter: Miscellaneous Hadiths (18/125 - Sharh Al-Nawawi).
2. Ibn Sa'di, Al-Wasa'il Al-Mufidah lil-Hayat Al-Sa'idah, p. 11-12, 4th Edition, General Presidency for Scientific Research and Ifta Departments, 1409 AH.
3. Al-Tawdih li Shajarat Al-Iman p. 73-74.
4. Madarij Al-Salikin (2/223).

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
22 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: That faith is the refuge of believers in everything that befalls them of joy and sadness, fear and security, obedience and disobedience, and other matters that are inevitable for everyone. So at times of beloved things and joy, they turn to faith, praising Allah, extolling Him, and using the blessings in what the Bestower loves. And at times of dislikes and sorrows, they turn to faith from several aspects: They console themselves with their faith and its sweetness. They console themselves with the consequent reward. And they meet sorrows and anxiety with peace of heart, and returning to the good life that resists sorrows and grieves. They turn to faith at times of fear, finding reassurance in it, and it increases them in faith, steadfastness, strength, and courage, and the fear that befell them fades away. Allah Almighty says: {Those to whom hypocrites said, "Indeed, the people have gathered against you, so fear them." But it [only] increased them in faith, while they said, "Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs." (173) So they returned with favor from Allah and bounty, no harm having touched them. And they pursued the pleasure of Allah, and Allah is the possessor of great bounty (174)} [Ali 'Imran: 173-174] (1). And they turn to faith if they are tested with some disobedience by initiating repentance from it, and doing what they can of good deeds to mend its deficiency. Allah Almighty says: {Indeed, those who fear Allah - when an impulse touches them from Satan, they remember [Him] and at once they have insight (201)} [Al-A'raf: 201] (2).
23 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: That belief in Predestination is part of the happiness of the son of Adam, and his discontent is part of his misery. On the authority of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "From the happiness of the son of Adam: Seeking Allah's choice (Istikhara), and from the happiness of the son of Adam: His satisfaction with what Allah decreed. And from the misery of the son of Adam: His discontent with what Allah decreed, and from the misery of the son of Adam: Abandoning seeking Allah's choice" (3). So satisfaction with the decree is one of the causes of happiness, and discontent with the decree is one of the causes of misery (4).
foot_note:
1. Al-Tawdih li Shajarat Al-Iman p. 86-88.
2. Usul Al-Tarbiyah Al-Islamiyyah p. 102-103.
3. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, Chapter: What came regarding satisfaction with Predestination, and it is in Da'if Sunan Al-Tirmidhi by Al-Albani, No. 381, 1st Edition, Al-Maktab Al-Islami, Beirut, 1411 AH.
4. Madarij Al-Salikin (2/208).

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
24 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Steadfastness and composure in facing calamities. Allah Almighty says: {No disaster strikes upon the earth or among yourselves except that it is in a register before We bring it into being - indeed that, for Allah, is easy - (22) In order that you not despair over what has eluded you and not exult [in pride] over what He has given you. And Allah does not like everyone self-deluded and boastful (23)} [Al-Hadid: 22-23]. Sheikh Abdur-Rahman Al-Sa'di said: (The Almighty says, informing about the generality of His decree and predestination: {No disaster strikes upon the earth or among yourselves}, and this includes the generality of calamities that strike creation, of good and evil. All of them have been written in the Preserved Tablet, small and large. This is a great matter that minds cannot encompass, rather the hearts of those of understanding are bewildered by it, but for Allah it is easy. Allah informed His servants of this so that this rule becomes established with them, and they base upon it what befalls them of good and evil. So they do not despair and grieve over what they missed, of what their souls aspired to and looked forward to, knowing that it is written in the Preserved Tablet, it must be executed and occur, there is no way to repel it. And they do not rejoice with what Allah gave them a joy of arrogance and insolence, knowing that they did not attain it by their power and strength, but rather attained it by Allah's favor and bounty. So they occupy themselves with thanking the Bestower of blessings and repelling punishments. Therefore He said: {And Allah does not like everyone self-deluded and boastful (23)}, meaning: arrogant, rude, coarse, self-admiring, boastful of Allah's blessings, attributing them to himself, and they make him transgress and distract him) (1). So when a person is balanced in his feelings in accepting calamities or joys, he becomes reassured in his life and stable in it as well (2).
25 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Upbringing on rationality and not explaining matters according to one's whim and interest. Rather, one must know that every cosmic phenomenon has benefits and harms, so he seeks its benefits and avoids its harms (3).
26 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Jihad, courage, and daring. Muslims became the bravest people and the most skilled horsemen. They used to fight enemies, keen on martyrdom, and keen to be in the front lines. No force terrified them and no multitude disturbed them, because the Muslim knows that weapons do not kill except the one whose term has approached. They knew that their refraining from Jihad in the way of Allah would not lift their term from them nor delay them an hour of the day (4).
foot_note:
1. Tafsir Al-Sa'di: 842.
2. Abdullah Al-Khater, Al-Huzn wa Al-Ikti'ab fi Daw' Al-Kitab wa Al-Sunnah, p. 35-37, Al-Muntada Al-Islami Edition, London.
3. Abdur-Rahman Al-Nahlawi, Usul Al-Tarbiyah Al-Islamiyyah wa Asalibuha fi Al-Bayt wa Al-Madrasah wa Al-Mujtama', p. 104, 2nd Edition, Dar Al-Fikr, Damascus, 1403 AH.
4. Sheikh Abdur-Rahman Al-Dawsari, and Saleh Al-Luhaidan, Tape: Athar Al-Iman bil-Qada' wa Al-Qadar 'ala Al-Mu'min, Tasjilat Al-Taqwa, No. 3362.

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
For the one who believes in Predestination knows that he will not die until his term comes, and nothing will touch him except what is written for him. So he advances unafraid and indifferent to the harm and calamities that befall him in the way of Allah. Allah Almighty said: {And it is not [possible] for one to die except by permission of Allah at a decree determined} [Ali 'Imran: 145]. And as the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said:
On which day of death shall I flee?
The day it is not decreed or the day it is decreed?
The day it is not decreed, I do not fear it.
And if it is decreed, caution will not save (1).
(If the believer is raised on daring before death, he becomes daring before everything. Before loss of wealth, child, or status, or before illness or any other calamity, as long as he believes that it is destined by Allah) (2).
27 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Calling to Allah (Da'wah). The correct understanding of belief in Predestination among the righteous Salaf was an incentive for them to spread the call to Allah. It made them strive to spread Islam in all parts of the earth, bear the harm in that, and be patient with it, knowing that what befell them was only by Allah's decree and predestination. We find that Islam extended from the ocean in the west to India in the east in a period of time not exceeding half a century! Which is a speed unmatched in history! With Islam spread the authority of the Islamic state in a way that terrified the enemies of Allah, and with it spread the Arabic tongue with a speed beyond description in the spread of languages.
28 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Optimism and cutting off the root of pessimism. Pessimism is explaining calamities by incorrect causes or reasons, such as pessimism from the sound of an owl, or from disease, or from time and its events, or from the wind. The believer in Divine Decree and Predestination knows that everything is by Allah's estimation and decree, and that what Allah wills happens and what He does not will does not happen: {They said, "Indeed, we consider you a bad omen. If you do not desist, we will surely stone you, and there will surely touch you, from us, a painful punishment." (18) They said, "Your omen is with yourselves. Is it because you were reminded? Rather, you are a transgressing people."} [Ya-Sin: 18-19] (3).
foot_note:
1. Diwan Al-Imam Ali p. 79-80 quoted from Al-Qada' wa Al-Qadar by Al-Hamad p. 25.
2. Usul Al-Tarbiyah Al-Islamiyyah wa Asalibuha fi Al-Bayt wa Al-Madrasah wa Al-Mujtama', p. 102.
3. Previous reference: p. 102.

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
29 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Not despairing of the victory of truth. For Allah Almighty has decreed that permanence is for the truth, because it is the origin upon which the heavens and earth were established, while falsehood is transient and vanishing. Allah Almighty says: {And say, "Truth has come, and falsehood has departed. Indeed is falsehood, [by nature], ever bound to depart." (81)} [Al-Isra: 81]. And Glory be to Him says: {So it goes as scum. But as for that which benefits the people, it remains on the earth. Thus does Allah set forth examples. (17) For those who responded...} [Ar-Ra'd: 17]. However, the profound wisdom of Allah Almighty required that falsehood exists to test His allies and to manifest the effects of His Beautiful Names and Lofty Attributes, and to test the believers with a goodly test. Otherwise, if Allah Almighty willed, there would be no disbelief or falsehood. Allah Almighty says: {That [is the command]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken vengeance upon them [Himself], but [He ordered armed struggle] to test some of you by means of others} [Muhammad: 4]. So the believer in Predestination knows with certainty that the outcome is for the righteous and that Allah's decree in that is effective inevitably, so despair does not creep into his heart, nor does it know a way to him no matter how intense the darkness of falsehood becomes.
30 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: High aspiration, not being satisfied with inferiority, and not being satisfied with painful reality. The believer in Predestination, you find him of high aspiration, not satisfied with inferiority nor with the bitter painful reality, and does not surrender to it using Predestination as an excuse, since this is not the place for using Predestination as an excuse because it is among the defects (Ma'ayib), and using Predestination as an excuse is only permissible in calamities not in defects. Rather, his belief in Predestination necessitates that he strives diligently to change this reality according to his ability and capacity.
31 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Determination and eliminating hesitation. There is no one in human societies more resolute than the believer in Allah's decree. If he discusses matters, weighs them, consults others, and seeks guidance from his Lord (Istikhara), he proceeds with what he has decided upon, without stopping, hesitation, or fear, due to his certainty that all circumstances and probabilities that might be outside his power and calculation are part of what occurred in Allah's knowledge and decree, and that Allah supports him. So if what he decided is facilitated for him, it is the good decreed for him, or for Allah to divert from him an evil that was probable (1).
32 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Seriousness and firmness in matters, and keenness for every religious or worldly good. The Messenger, peace be upon him, condemned sluggishness and laziness, and taught us this supplication: "O Allah, I seek refuge in You from worry and grief, and I seek refuge in You from incapacity and laziness, and I seek refuge in You from being overcome by debt and the oppression of men" (2).
foot_note:
1. Usul Al-Tarbiyah Al-Islamiyyah p. 101.
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Book of Supplications, Chapter: Seeking refuge from the oppression of men, (11/173 - Fath Al-Bari).

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
And as in his saying, peace be upon him: "Be keen on what benefits you, seek help from Allah, and do not be incapable. And if something befalls you, do not say: If only I had done such and such, it would have been such and such. But say: Allah decreed and what He willed He did" (1). So do not say: If only I had done and done and done, and remain blaming yourself and living on a past you regret. The Muslim must have a strong psyche, so if he errs, or a problem happens to him, he says: "Allah decreed and what He willed He did" and starts anew and works for the future (2).
33 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: That belief in Predestination negates from him the afflictions of greed and voracity for the world. That is the head of every sin, the origin of every tribulation, and the basis of every calamity. So his satisfaction with his Lord in all states negates from him the substance of these afflictions. (3)
34 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Generosity. For the one who believes in Predestination, and that poverty and wealth are in the hand of Allah, and that he will not become poor unless Allah decrees that for him - he spends and does not care. Because he knows that his wealth is by Allah's decree and predestination, and that the poverty of the poor is by Allah's decree and predestination, so he thanks Allah for this blessing, which drives him to spend in the way of Allah.
35 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Patience, seeking reward, and facing dangers and difficulties. For those who do not believe in Predestination, panic might lead some of them to disbelieve in Allah, some go mad, some become obsessive, some resort to drugs, and some kill themselves. That is why suicide is frequent in countries whose people do not believe in Predestination. Allah Almighty says: {But perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you; and perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you. And Allah Knows, while you know not (216)} [Al-Baqarah: 216]. (One of the secrets of this verse: is that it requires the servant to delegate to the One who knows the consequences of matters, and to be satisfied with what He chooses for him and decrees for him, hoping for a good outcome in it. So if he delegates to his Lord, and is satisfied with what He chooses for him, He supplies him in what He chooses for him with strength, determination, and patience, and diverts from him the afflictions that the servant's choice for himself is exposed to, and shows him of the good consequences of His choice for him what he would not have reached part of, by what he chooses for himself). (4)
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim, Book of Predestination, Chapter: Belief in Predestination and Submission to It (16/215 - Sharh Al-Nawawi).
2. Abdullah Al-Khater, Al-Hazimah Al-Nafsiyyah 'Inda Al-Muslimin, p. 54-55, 1st Edition, Al-Muntada Al-Islami, London, 1412 AH.
3. Madarij Al-Salikin (2/209).
4. Al-Fawa'id p. 175-176.

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
36 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Consolation for calamities and tribulation. Because the companionship of faith and certainty is the greatest consoler for them and alleviator of them, due to the strength of his faith, the strength of his reliance, the strength of his hope for his Lord's reward, and his greed for His bounty. So the first thing that alleviates tribulation and calamities is the issue of belief in Divine Decree and Predestination. So he does not panic, nor wail like the wailing of Jahiliyyah, nor get angry at disasters and accidents because he knows that what befell him was not to miss him and what missed him was not to befall him. So calamities become easy for him and he is always remembering the saying of the Messenger, peace be upon him: "Allah decreed and what He willed He did" (1).
37 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Lack of regret or sorrow over what has passed. The believer does not wail over the past with regret and sorrow, because that will not return anything of what passed, and because it only happened according to what Allah wrote for him. There is no objection to Allah's decree as long as it has occurred, but he can take a lesson, so he repents from the mistake or sin, and does not get bitten from the same hole twice (2).
38 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Acknowledging Allah's favor and bounty and expelling self-admiration when attaining the desired. The believer does not attribute good to himself, but to Allah Blessed and Exalted, because obtaining that is a blessing from Allah through the means of good and success He decreed, so he thanks Allah Almighty for that (3). So he does not admire himself nor boast of his work, knowing that Allah Almighty is the One who favored him with success and assistance and diverting obstacles and impediments, and that if he were left to himself, he would be weak and incapable of action (4).
39 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Not being deluded by deeds. Because the believer does not know what the result of the deed is, even guidance, he does not know what its result is, as the Messenger, peace be upon him, said: "By Allah, I am the Messenger of Allah, yet I do not know what will be done with me." Umm Al-Ala, may Allah be pleased with her, said - having praised Uthman bin Maz'un when he died: "Allah has honored you." The Messenger of Allah said to her: "And how do you know that Allah has honored him?" She said: Glory be to Allah, O Messenger of Allah, and whom does Allah honor if He does not honor him? The Messenger of Allah said to her: "By Allah, I am the Messenger of Allah, yet I do not know what will be done with me" (5).
40 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Acknowledging sin and error. The believing servant attributes shortcoming to himself forever and does not attribute it to Allah Almighty. If he falls into disobedience, he attributes it to himself, so that drives him to seeking forgiveness and repentance.
foot_note:
1. Previously referenced p. 36 footnote No. 2.
2. Usul Al-Tarbiyah Al-Islamiyyah p. 102.
3. Aqidah Ahl Al-Sunnah wa Al-Jama'ah, Ibn Uthaymeen, p. 47, 3rd Edition, Department of Scientific Research and Ifta, Riyadh, 1416 AH.
4. Al-Tanbihat Al-Latifah, p. 84.
5. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Book of Funerals, Chapter: Entering upon the deceased after death when wrapped in his shrouds (3/114 - Fath Al-Bari).

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
41 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Emulating the Prophets, peace be upon them. For the sinner, if he seeks forgiveness from his Lord for his sin, has emulated the happy ones among the Prophets and believers like Adam, peace be upon him, and others. But if he persists and uses Predestination as an excuse, he has emulated the wretched ones, like Iblis and those who followed him among the misguided (1).
42 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Strength of faith. For he who believes in Predestination, his faith strengthens, so he does not abandon it nor waver or weaken no matter what befalls him in that path. Due to his saying, peace be upon him: "The strong believer is better and more beloved to Allah than the weak believer, and there is good in both" (2).
43 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Guidance. As in the saying of the Almighty: {No disaster strikes except by permission of Allah. And whoever believes in Allah - He will guide his heart} [At-Taghabun: 11]. Some of the Salaf said: He is the man whom a calamity strikes, so he knows it is from Allah, so he is pleased and submits (3). So if the servant is struck by a calamity and believes it is from Allah, and that Allah is Wise and Merciful in decreeing it, and that He knows best the interests of His servant, Allah guides his heart a special guidance to satisfaction, patience, submission, and reassurance (4).
44 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Self-esteem, contentment, and freedom from the slavery of creatures. (Whoever fills his heart with satisfaction with Predestination, Allah fills his chest with richness, security, and contentment. And He empties his heart for His love, turning to Him, and relying on Him. And whoever misses his share of satisfaction, his heart fills with the opposite of that. And he becomes occupied away from what contains his happiness and success. So satisfaction empties the heart for Allah, and discontent empties the heart of Allah) (5).
foot_note:

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text:
The believer in Predestination knows that his provision is written, and that he will not die until he completes his provision. He realizes that Allah suffices him, is his reckoner and provider, and that servants, no matter how much they try to deliver provision to him or prevent it from him, will not be able to except with something Allah has written. So he is moved by that to contentment, self-esteem, moderation in seeking, abandoning greed for the world, freedom from the slavery of creatures, cutting off hope from what is in their hands, and directing the heart to the Lord of the worlds. This is the foundation of his success and the head of his achievement. Among the beautiful things mentioned in this meaning is what is attributed to the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, saying:
Contentment granted me every honor ... And is there an honor more honored than contentment?
So make it for yourself a capital ... And make piety after it a merchandise.
You will gain profit and be free from a miser ... And enjoy in Gardens by patience of an hour (1).
And from that is the saying of Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him:
I saw contentment as the treasure of richness ... So I became holding fast to its tails.
So neither this one sees me at his door ... Nor that one sees me engrossed with him.
And I became rich without a dirham ... I pass by people like a king (2).
45 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Not relying on soothsayers, astrologers, sorcerers, wiping on the dust of graves, supplicating to other than Allah, and directing any type of worship to other than Allah, because they do not possess for themselves benefit or harm, let alone for others.
46 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Emptying the heart of distractions. For belief in Predestination in the correct manner (relieves him from the exhausting thoughts in types of choices, and empties his heart from estimations and arrangements from which he ascends a steep path and descends another. And with this, there is no escape for him from what was destined for him. So if he is pleased with Allah's choice, the decree befalls him while he is praised, thanked, and treated kindly in it. Otherwise, the decree runs upon him while he is blamed, not treated kindly in it, because it is with his choice for himself. And when his delegation and satisfaction are sound, kindness towards him and gentleness with him encompass him in the decreed matter. So he becomes between His kindness and gentleness; His kindness protects him from what he fears, and His gentleness eases for him what He decreed) (3). So the way of the believer is to rise to the clear duties - as much as he can - and to avoid the specific prohibitions as forbidden. And to occupy himself with knowing what Allah commanded and what Allah forbade, and not to search into anything beyond them from the matter of the Unseen which is veiled from his limited perception. And Allah Glory be to Him would not burden him with something He knows he has no power to do, or that he is prevented by a compelling barrier from rising to. And Allah Glory be to Him would not forbid him from something He knows he has no power to refrain from, or that he is driven by a compelling irresistible motive to commit! Allah Almighty says: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity. It will have [the consequence of] what [good] it has gained, and it will bear [the consequence of] what [evil] it has earned} [Al-Baqarah: 286].
47 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Tranquility of the heart, peace of mind, and comfort of thought. These matters are fruits of belief in Divine Decree and Predestination, and they are an urgent demand and a desired goal. Everyone on the face of the earth seeks them and searches for them, but as it was said: Everyone in existence seeks a prey, but the nets are different. So no one realizes these matters, nor finds their sweetness, nor knows their fruit except he who believes in Allah and His Decree and Predestination. That is (because when he knows that it is by the decree of Allah Almighty and that the disliked thing is inevitable, the soul relaxes, the heart is reassured, and is pleased with the Lord's decree. So no one has a better life, more restful soul, and stronger reassurance than the one who believes in Predestination) (4). And indeed you find among the elite Muslims of working scholars and obedient following worshippers, a tranquility of heart and peace of mind that does not cross a mind, nor does an imagination revolve around its likeness. They have in that matter the highest arrow (greatest share) and the fullest portion. This is the Commander of the Faithful Umar bin Abdul Aziz, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: (I have become having no joy except in the places of Predestination. It was said to him: What do you desire? He said: What Allah Mighty and Majestic decrees) (5). And this is Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, saying: (Indeed, there is a paradise in this world, whoever does not enter it will not enter the Paradise of the Hereafter) (6). And he says his famous statement which he said when he was led to prison: (What can my enemies do to me? My paradise and my garden are in my chest; wherever I travel, they are with me, never leaving me. My imprisonment is seclusion, my killing is martyrdom, and my expulsion from my land is tourism) (7).
49 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Expelling anxiety and boredom when missing what is desired or occurrence of the disliked. Because that is by the decree of Allah Almighty who owns the kingdom of the heavens and earth and it is inevitable, so he endures that patiently and seeks the reward (8).

text:
50 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Humility. For the believer in Predestination, if Allah provides him with wealth, status, knowledge, or other than that, he humbles himself to Allah, knowing that this is from Allah, and if He willed, He would take it away from him. He is over all things competent. Allah Almighty says: {Say, "O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty, You give sovereignty to whom You will and You take sovereignty away from whom You will. You honor whom You will and You humble whom You will. In Your hand is [all] good. Indeed, You are over all things competent (26)} [Ali 'Imran: 26].
51 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Gratitude. For the believer in Predestination knows that whatever blessing he has is from Allah alone, and that Allah is the Repeller of every dislike and vengeance. So he is moved by that to thank Allah, as He is the Gracious Bestower who destined that for him, and He is the One deserving of thanks. Allah Almighty says about Solomon, peace be upon him: {And he said, "My Lord, enable me to be grateful for Your favor which You have bestowed upon me and upon my parents} [An-Naml: 19].
52 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Satisfaction (Rida). (Indeed, the Wisest of judges, the Most Merciful of the merciful, and the Most Knowing of knowers, who is more merciful to His servants than they are to themselves and than their fathers and mothers, if He sends down upon them what they dislike, it is better for them than not sending it down upon them, out of care from Him for them, benevolence to them, and kindness to them. If they were enabled to choose for themselves, they would be unable to undertake their interests in knowledge, will, and action. But He, Glory be to Him, took charge of managing their affairs according to His knowledge, wisdom, and mercy, whether they liked it or disliked it. Those certain of His Names and Attributes knew that, so they did not dispute His management, nor impugn His wisdom, nor disobey His judgment. They did not oppose His judgment with their corrupt minds, false opinions, and unjust policies. Thus, they neither knew their Lord nor obtained their interests. And when the servant succeeds in this knowledge, he dwells in this world before the Hereafter in a paradise whose bliss resembles only the bliss of the Hereafter. For he remains satisfied with his Lord, and satisfaction is the paradise of the world, and the resting place of the knowers. For it is the goodness of the soul with what runs upon it of the decrees which are the very choice of Allah for it, and its reassurance to His religious rulings. This is satisfaction with Allah as Lord, Islam as religion, and Muhammad as Messenger. And he has not tasted the taste of faith who has not obtained that. This satisfaction is according to his knowledge of Allah's justice, wisdom, mercy, and good choice. So the more he knows that, the more satisfied he is with Him. For the Lord's decree, Glory be to Him, regarding His servant revolves between justice, interest, wisdom, and mercy; it never departs from that at all. As he, peace be upon him, said in the famous supplication: "O Allah! I am Your servant, son of Your servant, son of Your maidservant, my forelock is in Your Hand, Your command over me is forever executed and Your decree over me is just. I ask You by every Name belonging to You which You named Yourself with, or revealed in Your Book, or You taught to any of Your creation, or You have preserved in the knowledge of the unseen with You, that You make the Quran the spring of my heart and the light of my chest, and a departure for my sorrow and a release for my anxiety and distress. No one ever said it except that Allah removed his anxiety and distress and replaced it with relief." They said: Should we not learn them, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "Yes! It befits the one who hears them to learn them" (1).

text:
The intended meaning is his saying: "Your decree over me is just." This covers every decree He decrees upon His servant, of punishment or pain and the cause of that. For He is the One who decreed the cause and decreed the effect, and He is just in this decree. This decree is good for the believer, as he, peace be upon him, said: "By the One in Whose hand is my soul, Allah does not decree a decree for the believer except that it is good for him, and that is for no one except the believer" (1) (2). So he is pleased with Allah as a Lord, Manager, and Legislator, so his soul fills with satisfaction with his Lord, and if he is pleased with Allah, Allah Almighty pleases him.
53 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Joy. So the believer in Predestination rejoices in that faith which many nations were deprived of: {(57) Say, "In the bounty of Allah and in His mercy - in that let them rejoice; it is better than what they accumulate."} [Yunus: 58].
54 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Love and lack of envy among believers. Because belief in Predestination and (Satisfaction opens for him the door of safety, making his heart sound and pure from deceit, treachery, and rancor. And none is saved from Allah's punishment except one who comes to Allah with a sound heart. Likewise, the soundness of the heart is impossible with discontent and lack of satisfaction. For malice, treachery, and deceit: are the companion of discontent. And the soundness of the heart, its righteousness, and its advice: are the companion of satisfaction. Likewise, envy: is one of the fruits of discontent. And the soundness of the heart is from the fruits of satisfaction) (3). So the believer does not envy people for what Allah has given them of His bounty, due to his belief that Allah is the One who provided for them, and decreed that for them. He gives to whom He wills, and withholds from whom He wills, as a test and trial from Him, Mighty and Majestic, and that when he envies another, he is actually objecting to Predestination (4).
55 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Enraging the innovators who control Allah's wisdom and law (5). They say Allah should do such and such, or they negate Allah's wisdom in His actions. Belief in Predestination according to Ahlus-Sunnah enrages them because they submit to the cosmic and legal commands.
56 - Among the fruits of belief in Predestination: Steadfastness on a straight path in prosperity and adversity. For servants have shortcomings, deficiencies, and weakness; they do not remain steadfast on a straight path except the one who believes in Predestination. For the blessing does not make him insolent, and the calamity does not make him despair.

Chapter Five: Secularism (1) and its Connection to Deviation in the Concept of Predestination
Indeed, the creed (when it was sound, and faith was strong and overflowing, and adherence to what Allah commanded of precaution, caution, and preparation of strength and capability was established, it was not possible in any way for intellectual invasion to find an outlet to penetrate. And if it found an outlet, it would not find a place to influence. And if it found a place, in the rarest of cases that might happen, but it would quickly be resisted and treated. All this happens in the state of the Ummah's wakefulness and awareness, and in the state of the dominance of the creed and its pulse. In the days when the Ummah was like that, the currents of intellectual invasion did not affect it, and found no way to penetrate it. But after deviations covered the life of the Ummah, and weakness afflicted its creed, it became an expected matter that it would become a target for campaigns of intellectual invasion, and fall prey to them from the first moment it collided with them) (2).
Among these (dangerous deviations that appeared in the history of the Ummah and which still exist to our time, is what is called Sufism (3). This sect with which Islam and Muslims were afflicted, and which over time became many paths and numerous sects. Sufism is one of the greatest calamities that Islam has been afflicted with throughout its history, and which inflicted upon Muslims what only Allah knows of weakness, frailty, subservience, and submission to the painful reality without attempting to change it) (4).
foot_note:
1. Secularism (Al-'Ilmaniyyah): The term 'Ilmaniyyah' is an incorrect translation of the word (Secularism) in English or (Secularite) in French. It is a word that has no connection to the word 'Ilm' (science/knowledge) and its derivatives at all. The correct translation of the word is "Irreligion" (Al-La Diniyyah) or "Worldliness" (Al-Dunyawiyyah), not just in the sense of opposing the Hereafter, but in a more specific sense which is what has no connection to religion, or whose relationship with religion is one of opposition. It is a social movement aiming to divert people and direct them from concern for the Hereafter to concern for this world alone. So the correct expression for Secularism is "establishing life on other than religion" whether for the nation or the individual.

text:
Secularism exploited the deviation in Islamic concepts among the Sufis - including the deviation in the concept of Predestination and Reliance (Tawakkul) - as one of the manifestations of intellectual invasion to tell people that religion has no relation to life or practical behavior, but rather it is a spiritual bond between the servant and his Lord by which he deserves salvation and success in the other world.
In explaining the deviation of Sufis regarding Predestination, Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, says: (As for the "Second Sect" - meaning among the misguided sects engaging in Predestination - they are worse than them - meaning the Qadariyyah. They are groups from the people of path (Suluk), will (Iradah), godliness (Ta'alluh), Sufism, and poverty (Faqr) and the like. They witness this truth, and saw that Allah is the Creator of all creatures, so He is the Creator of the servants' actions and the Willer of all beings. But they did not distinguish after that between faith and disbelief, nor knowledge and denial, nor truth and falsehood, nor guided and astray, nor rashid and ghawi, nor prophet and false prophet, nor ally of Allah and enemy, nor pleasing and displeasing, nor beloved and hated, nor between justice and injustice, nor between righteousness and disobedience, nor between the deeds of Paradise and the deeds of the people of Fire, nor between the righteous and the wicked. As they witnessed what creatures share of the Pre-ordained Decree, the Executed Will, the Comprehensive Power, and the General Creation. So they witnessed the commonality between creatures and were blind to the distinction between them. And they became of those addressed by His saying Almighty: {(34) Then will We treat the Muslims like the criminals? (35) What is [the matter] with you? How do you judge?} [Al-Qalam: 35-36]) (1).
He also said: (And the second sect: - meaning among the misguided sects engaging in Predestination - the Mushrikun (Polytheists) - who acknowledged Divine Decree and Predestination, and claimed that it agrees with the Command and Prohibition, and they denied the Command and Prohibition. Allah Almighty says: {Those who associated with Allah will say, "If Allah had willed, we would not have associated [anything] and neither would our fathers, nor would we have prohibited anything."} [Al-An'am: 148]. And He says: {And those who associated others with Allah said, "If Allah had willed, we would not have worshipped anything other than Him, neither we nor our fathers, nor would we have prohibited anything without His permission."} [An-Nahl: 35]. So the affair of these leads to the suspension of Shari'a laws, the Command, and Prohibition, while acknowledging the general Lordship over every creature, and that there is no creature but my Lord holds its forelock. This is what many are afflicted with - either in belief or in state - groups of Sufis and Fuqara (poor ones), until some of them exit to the permissibility of prohibitions, the dropping of obligations, and the lifting of punishments) (2).

book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text: Then, as a result of this wrong understanding of the doctrine of Predestination, (the Sufis went to extremes in the concept of reliance on Allah (Tawakkul), and understood it wrongly. So they cut off taking means, abandoned caution and precaution, and interpreted Tawakkul with other than its legal meaning, thereby contradicting the Book and the Sunnah. Tawakkul among the Sufis became interpreted in a strange way, and applied in the life of the people in a strange application. Here is one of the major Sufis explaining the meaning of Tawakkul according to them, writing: (Al-Hasan, brother of Sinan, said: I performed Hajj fourteen times barefoot, relying [on Allah], and thorns would enter my foot, and I would not remove them, lest my reliance decreases). (And it was said: Whoever claims reliance and then becomes full has carried provisions). This type of reliance is enough to destroy societies and spread poverty among them, and may lead to the destruction of their people, and it is contrary to the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him (1). Indeed, (Tawakkul is the fruit of belief in Divine Decree and Predestination and its result, and therefore it is a creed associated with action.. Allah Almighty says: {And whoever relies upon Allah - then He is sufficient for him} [Yunus: 49]. And He says: {And when you have decided, then rely upon Allah. Indeed, Allah loves those who rely [upon Him] (159)} [Ali 'Imran: 159]. So whoever abandons action completely, he has not understood Tawakkul in its correct way, and that is blameworthy Tawakul (feigned reliance), which creates unemployment and produces loafers in the streets, or in Takayas and Zawiyas) (2). (However, Sufis see that Tawakkul conflicts with action, so it is a degree adhered to by those capable among them, in their negative way) (3). The Tawakul has corrupted much of the doctrine of Divine Decree and Predestination, turning it from a positive, motivating doctrine into a negative, discouraging doctrine, and into negative satisfaction with reality, and not attempting change. Napoleon Bonaparte exploited that deviant idea of Divine Decree and Predestination when his Crusader armies occupied the land of Egypt. He used to issue his proclamations reminding Muslims that what happened to them of occupation and captivity was by a decree from Allah, so whoever tries to object to what happened is as if he is objecting to Divine Decree and Predestination (4).

text: By this, the Sufis attempt to oppose the reality of this religion and clash with its clear texts in many deviations, which contributed to the backwardness of these societies, and letting the leadership of the caravan of civilization be taken by other misguided nations, after they were goodness, building, and reconstruction for all of humanity, the day they were walking on the guidance of this religion, and enlightened by its glowing light) (1). The Sheikhs brainwashed their followers so they believed every impossible thing, and believed what the stubborn Sheikh says. Their upbringing of followers was mostly a humiliating upbringing. book_title: The Doctrine of Belief in Divine Decree and Predestination according to the Salaf and its Effect on the Believer
text: One of the German orientalists wrote, chronicling the state of Muslims in their later eras, saying: The nature of the Muslim is submission to the will of Allah, satisfaction with His decree and predestination, and submission with all he owns to the One, the Subjugator. This obedience had two different effects. In the first Islamic era, it played a major role in war as it achieved continuous victory because it instilled the spirit of sacrifice in the soldier. In the later eras, it was a cause for the stagnation that overshadowed the Islamic world, throwing it into decline, isolating it, and folding it away from the currents of world events. This man, being a disbeliever, realized this truth: the truth of the difference between belief in Predestination as understood by the Salaf and the belief innovated by the Khalaf (successors) influenced by the Sufis. There is no doubt that what befell Muslims of humiliation, disgrace, and moral and sensory defeats was by the decree of Allah, in Whose dominion nothing occurs except what He wills, and nothing is hidden from Him, rather what was and what will be are equal in His knowledge. But Muslims in later eras distorted this concept and took belief in Predestination as a flimsy justification for their incapacity and collapse, forgetting that Allah's decrees run upon them according to His fixed laws which He clarified to them, but they overlooked them and neglected them. So the responsibility is theirs alone, and your Lord does not wrong anyone. Reliance (Tawakkul), which was the strong motive for the movement of Jihad and launching into the earth with the means of life, turned into cheap, blameworthy Tawakul (feigned reliance) which the Sufis called "certainty" (Yaqin) and others called "contentment" (Qana'ah) and everyone sought reward for it from Allah. Muslims surrendered to a long sleep - using Predestination as an excuse - and nothing woke them except the roar of Western civilization pounding their strongholds and storming their forts. It was the astounding surprise that shook the Ummah's faith in its religion, which was a dormant, cold faith with no movement. In this moment of dazzle and astonishment, the orientalists and missionaries and their tails said: That religion - and the doctrine of Predestination especially - is the cause of backwardness and stagnation in the Islamic world. The gullible ones believed them, those who knew nothing of the rituals of religion except what the Sheikhs of the paths drew for them of prayers and litanies, nor of its rules except that part of faith is for a person to be satisfied with what is written for him - according to the wrong understanding of it. In the name of asceticism in the world, and submissive surrender to humiliation and poverty - under the cover of belief in Predestination -, both of which were volunteered by the Sufi paths and encouraged by the ignorant, decadent environment - Islamic civilization retreated and withered until it breathed its last at the hands of the military and cultural invasion coming from the West. (Sufism became a Murji'i Jibriyyah patting the shoulders of the sleepers, so despair and hopelessness take over life... This negative view was the best help to the colonizer... who fed Sufism and spent a lot on its shrines and corners to kill the vitality and psychology of Jihad among Muslims) (1).

text:
Conclusion
Afterwards, it has become clear to us through this research that the foundation upon which the righteousness of the individual is built is the correct creed, firm belief in Allah Almighty, and what follows that of belief in Allah's decree and predestination. That is because belief in Divine Decree and Predestination has importance in the righteousness of the individual and the stability of his conditions, for there is no happiness for an individual who does not believe in Divine Decree and Predestination.
And that the believer should submit and believe in everything that came in the Book and the Sunnah regarding matters related to Divine Decree and Predestination, and understand them with the correct understanding upon which the predecessors of this Ummah from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, were, and those who followed their methodology from the Tabi'in and righteous scholars.
And that he should not delve into what he has no knowledge of. And that he should rely on Allah Almighty in all matters, small and large, and make that an aid to him for work and abandoning incapacity and laziness.
Our Lord, let not our hearts deviate after You have guided us and grant us from Yourself mercy. Indeed, You are the Bestower. And may Allah send blessings and peace upon our Prophet Muhammad and upon his family and companions.
